text:
1. Depends on the position. I doubt there's an expectation for you to do full keywords research or head to Ahrefs or anything, but if it looks like you've at least checked out competitor sites or the related searches topics, that's probably good enough!
2. If you've read enough content to feel like you have a surface-level idea of the voice, I'd trust your writer's instinct after that. IMO as long as it's not a complete 180 (like the site is a bloggy tone and you're writing like a it's a technical manual) that should show you're paying attention.

elements.text: Depends on the position. I doubt there's an expectation for you to do full keywords research or head to Ahrefs or anything, but if it looks like you've at least checked out competitor sites or the related searches topics, that's probably good enough!

If you've read enough content to feel like you have a surface-level idea of the voice, I'd trust your writer's instinct after that. IMO as long as it's not a complete 180 (like the site is a bloggy tone and you're writing like a it's a technical manual) that should show you're paying attention.

text: Does anyone have any examples of good thought leadership content they like? And a related question here: From your experience, who owns the thought leadership program in a company? Or at least, who should own it? I’m curious about how other companies have set it up: Is it the CEO/founders, the marketing department, or someone else within the org who owns thought leadership initiatives? Thanks!

text: re: ownership, I think the marketing department should "own" the program as far as scheduling, publishing, distributing, but i am *hardcore,* ride-or-die adamant that when it comes to the _substance_ of the content itself - i.e. the "thoughts" that are "leading" - those _really_ need to originate with... well... the leader, whether that's the CEO or the CTO if it's a technical subject.

elements.text: re: ownership, I think the marketing department should "own" the program as far as scheduling, publishing, distributing, but i am

really
need to originate with... well... the leader, whether that's the CEO or the CTO if it's a technical subject.

text: The trick is finding the right workflow between that high-level SME and the writer who's on tap to do the translating - obviously C-levels have a lot going on, so making the process of getting the knowledge from them and getting input on final drafts needs to be as low lift, low friction for them as possible

elements.text: The trick is finding the right workflow between that high-level SME and the writer who's on tap to do the translating - obviously C-levels have a lot going on, so making the process of getting the knowledge from them and getting input on final drafts needs to be as low lift, low friction for them as possible

text: As far as what it looks like, it really varies from person to person - some SMEs really can just hop on a 30-minute to one-hour call and speak in complete paragraphs that plant the seeds for  2-3 thought leadership articles, and you pretty much just have to hold your hands out and catch those insights

elements.text: As far as what it looks like, it really varies from person to person - some SMEs really can just hop on a 30-minute to one-hour call and speak in complete paragraphs that plant the seeds for  2-3 thought leadership articles, and you pretty much just have to hold your hands out and catch those insights

text: But other folks aren't external processors that way - they need to go away and noodle with an idea, put something down on paper themselves, even if it's in notes form

elements.text: But other folks aren't external processors that way - they need to go away and noodle with an idea, put something down on paper themselves, even if it's in notes form

text: And some people need help to even figure out what their "thought leadershippy" thoughts even are -- in those cases, I find it's good to feed them things -- often it's "hot take" tweets or posts from _other_ influencers in the industry -- and just get a reaction. That tends to get the ball rolling.

text: Once you _have_ the raw material to work with, that's where the writer really gets to shine - finding the attention-grabbing angle, shaping the story/flow so it reads like butter, etc. etc. etc.

text: re: examples, apart from the usual suspects (DHH, Chris Savage, Hiten Shah), Anil Dash puts out some good stuff - here's one post in particular that I really like:  <https://anildash.com/2016/08/19/there_is_no_technology_industry/>

attachments.title: There is no "technology industry"
attachments.text: The label’s become too big to be useful, and tech could suffer for it. Quick: What do an auto leasing provider, a condiment company and the producers of a serious TV drama have in common? If your answer is “almost nothing”, then you’re right. If your answer is
attachments.fallback: Anil Dash: There is no "technology industry"

elements.text: re: examples, apart from the usual suspects (DHH, Chris Savage, Hiten Shah), Anil Dash puts out some good stuff - here's one post in particular that I really like:

text: I tend to look to writers from outside the conventional content/content marketing world for inspiration:  Adam Grant, Malcolm Gladwell, Tim Wu -- they're all thought leaders, maybe even in a purer form than a CEO or other SME inside a company, because in their case the thought leadership itself _is_ the product that they're selling.

elements.text: I tend to look to writers from outside the conventional content/content marketing world for inspiration:  Adam Grant, Malcolm Gladwell, Tim Wu -- they're all thought leaders, maybe even in a purer form than a CEO or other SME inside a company, because in their case the thought leadership itself
is
the product that they're selling.

text:
re: ownership

I feel it should be the content vertical undoubtedly. Editorial assistants and researchers have the best sense of what goes down well, how the analytics teams deploy the content and what they reap from it. They would be the best curators.

Like several other affairs, it should be a concerted effort before a piece claiming to "thought-leadership" is brought out.

text:
So our CEO has asked if there’s any benefit in asking people to share our product launch content at the same time (you know, to take over twitter or whatever). 

My question is... is there? Anybody had any experience where this has been an absolutely must-do activity for future launches?

elements.text: So our CEO has asked if there’s any benefit in asking people to share our product launch content at the same time (you know, to take over twitter or whatever).
My question is... is there? Anybody had any experience where this has been an absolutely must-do activity for future launches?

text: Who are “people”?

elements.text: Who are “people”?

text: We have a journalists list, “friends of”, and influencers that I’d reach out to. I’m going to do this anyway but including a specific time to share seems 1) tacky and 2) unproductive

elements.text: We have a journalists list, “friends of”, and influencers that I’d reach out to. I’m going to do this anyway but including a specific time to share seems 1) tacky and 2) unproductive

text: Sorry for that. Seems my phone had a mind of its own :cry:

elements.text: Sorry for that. Seems my phone had a mind of its own

text: Asking relevant, engaged brand advoctes to share and giving them the launch date as a starting point, definitely a great way to extend the reach of your launch. Asking them to share at an exact time of day…I don’t know if that’s really going to do anything and especially if this is a favor and not paid promotion, might feel a little out of touch to ask for.  (This is for social amplification requests specifically and not re: pitching launch coverage under embargo to journalists.)

elements.text: Asking relevant, engaged brand advoctes to share and giving them the launch date as a starting point, definitely a great way to extend the reach of your launch. Asking them to share at an exact time of day…I don’t know if that’s really going to do anything and especially if this is a favor and not paid promotion, might feel a little out of touch to ask for.  (This is for social amplification requests specifically and not re: pitching launch coverage under embargo to journalists.)

text: This is great!

elements.text: This is great!

text:
Yeah I would exclude journalists from this altogether and just take them off the table outside of actually pitching them and giving them an embargo to work around.

The only people I would feel comfortable asking to share this or amplify our posts on something like this are investors, advisors and partners. People with a vested interest in the success of your company. Your CEO should be doing the outreach to investors and advisors. Whoever owns partner relationships or deals with them the most can handle partners.

For customers and advocates, you could get a little more creative and ask them to share their thoughts on a LinkedIn post or something when you break the news to them. Unless you have a gamified advocate marketing program, personally I wouldn’t waste asking customers to share the news to their own personal feeds. The exception to this might be the customers who have been asking for this product feature and who will be super excited that it’s finally arrived, if that’s a thing.

For customers and advocates, you could get a little more creative and ask them to share their thoughts on a LinkedIn post or something when you break the news to them. text:
>  My question is... is there? 
Yes, absolutely — timing is key. Social chatter about you compounds. As soon as engagement is popping off you’ll see you gain more visibility exponentially.

> Anybody had any experience where this has been an absolutely must-do activity for future launches?
For instance, launching on ProductHunt is very time sensitive and requires a ton of planning. You have 24 hours in which you need to go all out to become `product of the day`.

elements.text: My question is... is there?

Anybody had any experience where this has been an absolutely must-do activity for future launches?

product of the day

text: Since timing is so important, be sure to warm up that group of people that you’ll be calling upon. Let them know what you’ll need from them, and when you’ll need it.

elements.text: Since timing is so important, be sure to warm up that group of people that you’ll be calling upon. Let them know what you’ll need from them, and when you’ll need it.

text:
Yeah I would have some tough conversations about it internally and dig into the rationale. There certainly _can_ be benefits, but it depends on the purpose and the way you go about it. The way you’re asking the question makes it sound more like a CEO ego trip than something more impactful, but there might be something under there that’s important to the CEO. It might not necessarily be about reaching buyers, it might be about impressing investors or attracting key partners. So the tough conversations might need to be about:
• Who are we targeting with this “takeover”?
• What channel(s) are they actually likely to see this on? I would be surprised a B2B company would want to takeover Twitter and not LinkedIn.
• Who are the best people to reach our target audience?

It might not necessarily be about reaching buyers, it might be about impressing investors or attracting key partners. So the tough conversations might need to be about:
Who are we targeting with this “takeover”?
What channel(s) are they actually likely to see this on? I would be surprised a B2B company would want to takeover Twitter and not LinkedIn.
Who are the best people to reach our target audience?
